newsitem.title: ESTONIA: ESTONIAN METAL EXPORT SEEN FULLY SOLD BY YR END.
newsitem.headline: ESTONIAN METAL EXPORT SEEN FULLY SOLD BY YR END.

text.p: Estonia's Privatisation Agency on Thursday released the sale details for a 51 percent state-owned slice of Estonian Metal Export Ltd (EMEX), saying the rest of the company would be sold by the end of 1997.
The state will be left with a 44 percent slice of the company after this sale as a five percent holding was sold through a public offering last November/December.
"We would like to find a single buyer or a consortium to buy this 51 percent stake," the agency's director general Vaino Sarnet told Reuters in an interview.
"We want to find a strategic owner for this 51 percent. We consider this to be quite a good investment as it is a stable business.
"The other 44 percent will then be sold through a public offering in Estonia later in the year."
Bids for the 51 percent sale have to be received by May 8.
EMEX, with 207 staff, buys scrap metal in Estonia and Russia, processes it and then exports it to various markets including Germany, Britain, and Sweden.
Its turnover in 1996 was 301.7 million kroons and in 1995 386.1 million kroons with a pre-tax profit of 52.84 million kroons and net profit of 40.87 million kroons.

In 1995 EMEX bought a total of 219.6 million tonnes of ferrous scrap metal and 12 million tonnes of non-ferrous scrap metal. This was expected to have decreased by 10-15 percent in 1996 and slip further.
"Substantial increase in turnover and number of employees of EMEX can only take place by processing scrap metal coming from outside Estonia, primarily Russia," the agency said.
"So far the obstacle has been the export policy exercised by Russia and Lativa which includes high export customs for scrap metal and metal waste."
The company also owns three long-haul trucks which are mainly used to transport materials to Finland and several properties around Estonia.
The privatisation of EMEX is part of Estonia's ongoing programme established after the country regained independence in 1991 to privatise state owned businesses.
